title: During Norfolk murder trial, father describes last call with his son before shooting

content:
NORFOLK — Bilal Muhammad was on the phone with his son, Ali, when the trouble began.

During testimony Monday in Norfolk Circuit Court, Muhammed told jurors he’d called his son the night of June 29, 2023, to make sure he was up and headed to work, just as he did most nights that Ali was working.

Once Ali got to the parking lot of his apartment building, he told his father another car was blocking his vehicle.

“He said, ‘This guy got me blocked in,’ and ‘This guy won’t move his car,'” Muhammad testified. Next, he heard Ali repeatedly ask someone to “‘Get that gun out of my face.”

“Lord, have mercy. I’m praying,” Muhammad told jurors. “‘Will you please get that gun out of my face?’ Then pop. Just like that. Just like that.”

Muhammad never heard another word from his son. Ali Muhammad, 33 and the father of three young girls, had been shot once in the chest.

Muhammad called 911, then he and his wife, Cynthia, rushed to Ali’s apartment on 1st Bay Street in the Ocean View area. By the time they arrived, Ali had been pronounced dead.

Muhammad’s testimony came on the first day of trial for Jalen Garces. The 30-year-old Virginia Beach man is charged with second-degree murder and using a firearm to commit a felony.

Son of anti-violence activist shot and killed in Norfolk: ‘He was trying to go to work’

Also testifying Monday was a woman who was in the parking lot when the shooting happened. She told jurors she was sitting in her rental car, looking at her phone, when she heard people arguing.

She said she looked up, saw two people standing near a car, then looked back down at her phone. Moments later, she heard a single shot. When she looked up again, she saw one person get into the driver’s seat of a dark-colored Mustang and drive away. The other person was lying face-down in a pool of blood. She called 911, gave a description of the car to the dispatcher, as well as the direction it was headed.

During opening statements, Assistant Commonwealth’s Attorney Liane Galardi told jurors the description she provided of the fleeing car — as well as the direction it was going — was crucial to the case.

Investigators located footage from Flock camera surveillance systems to track down the license plate on a black Mustang that had been in the area at the time of the shooting, Galardi said. Surveillance footage recorded that same night at a Wawa convenience store and a Virginia ABC liquor store showed it was Garces who was driving it.

Virginia Beach police pulled Garces over in the Mustang a couple of days later, arrested him, and seized the car. Data download from the car, as well as from Garces’ cell phone, showed he was at the scene when the shooting happened, Galardi said.

“That car tells us that he killed Ali,” the prosecutor said.

Defense attorney Daymen Robinson told jurors Garces wasn’t involved in the shooting. He suggested that two other residents of the apartment building who’d previously had altercations with Ali may have been responsible.

Robinson said detectives became so hyper-focused on the Mustang, that they failed to consider other possibilities.

“They had this one piece of evidence and they tied their entire case to it,” the defense lawyer said.

Testimony in the trial is set to resume Tuesday. It’s expected to last three to four days.
summary: Bilal Muhammad, the father of slain anti-violence activist Ali Muhammad, testified in the trial of his son, Jalen Garces, who is charged with second-degree murder and using a firearm to commit a felony. During testimony, Muhammad described the last call with his son before he was shot in the chest on June 29, 2023. He and his wife rushed to his son's apartment and pronounced him dead by the time they arrived. A witness who witnessed the shooting described a fleeing car and its direction as crucial evidence in the case. Garces was arrested a few days later and seized the car. The trial is set to resume on Tuesday.
shortSummary: Bilal Muhammad testified about the last call he had with his son before he was killed by a car blockage in Norfolk, prompting a murder trial.
argos_summary: Bilal Muhammad testified in court about the tragic shooting of his son, Ali, who was killed on June 29, 2023, after being blocked in a parking lot. Ali was shot in the chest during a confrontation, and witnesses described the scene, including a woman who saw a dark-colored Mustang leave the area shortly after the gunshot. Jalen Garces, the accused, is charged with second-degree murder, and evidence including surveillance footage and data from his vehicle and cell phone reportedly links him to the crime, although his defense argues that other suspects should be considered.
